children.subject: No, not unless both classes suddenly allowed time conflicts.
PSA: the situation above does actually work! I just tried, and it was successful
(All I had to do was enroll in class B after class A allowed time conflicts)

Thanks for this doc! I am currently enrolled in class A (currently not allowing time conflicts) because that class fills up much faster than class B (currently not allowing time conflicts).

The professor of class A said they will start allowing time conflicts. Is there any way I can in one shot get enrolled in both classes without losing my spot in class A?
For that you should email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu to ask for assistance.

Hi,

I enrolled in EECS 127 which doesn't allow time conflicts and then I tried to enroll in EE 123 which does allow time conflicts, but I wasn't able to enroll due to 127 not allowing time conflicts. How do I go about enrolling in both?
I have a class conflict with 61c, and it says the class allows time conflicts, but should I email the prof to double check they will offer an alt final exam time?
+1 @Cindy if you can pls answer this question

Please read what I wrote above.

Try enrolling in CS 170 FIRST because then there's no time conflict for the system to 'see'. Once you're enrolled in that class THEN try enrolling in Data 100. In theory the system will allow you to enroll because there's no check on the Data 100 class to look for & prevent time conflicts.

Again, I have to issue my warning - if there's any sort of conflict with exams, you need to seek alternates from the faculty for Data 100. CS 170 is making no accommodations.

I am an intended CS transfer and planning to take CS 170 and DATA 100. I'm already in DATA 100 and stuck on the waitlist of CS 170. Does it mean I cannot enroll in CS 170 even after the adjustment period starts? Can a CS advisor manually override the status if the system rejects my enrollment?

No, it means you need to wait for seats to open up before you will be enrolled. Once the adjustment period begins the reserved seat rules come down & the waitlist will fill any open seats solely based on the WL position.

Just to clarify, will the system not check time conflicts when it fills open seats with people on the waitlist? I am worried because I am already in DATA 100 which allows time conflicts and waiting for the adjustment period for CS 170 that does not allow time conflicts. That is against the recommended order of enrollment when one allows time conflicts and the other doesn't.

Thank you for clarifying - yes, that IS a problem. The system DOES check for time conflicts before it fills seats for CS 170 so you will remain stuck on the waitlist in the scenario you describe.

The only 'solution' is to drop Data 100, wait until you are enrolled in CS 170 and then re-enroll into Data 100. (Of course, this solution assumes seats are easy to come by for both of these classes.)

You may well need to develop an alternate plan where you defer taking CS 170 another semester & keep your seat in Data 100, or you may want to defer taking Data 100 over the summer or in another semester if you are able.
Since CS170 doesn't allow time conflicts but Data 100 allows for time conflicts, will Cal Central allow me to enroll in both?

The rule is temporary but applies across campus. It may be that the professor is okay with the time conflict but the class isn't set up in the system to allow time conflicts. I recommend contacting the Scheduler/Enrollment Manager for the Philosophy dept to ask if they can help you enroll or at least confirm the setting in the system.

This semester I enrolled in a EECS course which does not allow time conflict, then enrolled in a course offered by the Department of Philosophy which does allow time conflict and does not have final exam. I confirmed with the professor for the Philosophy course and it is confirmed that the class indeed does allow time conflict, but CalCentral denied my request to add that course.

So, is this rule temporary or does it only apply to this semester/EECS department?

Since it's up to each professor to decide how they will proctor their exams and if they will offer alternate exams, you need to direct these questions to them. 

This information was released last April but I believe it's still relevant and may provide you some insight to Campus' thinking on this topic. https://evcp.berkeley.edu/news/proctoring-and-final-examinations

<md>How does this impact students in other timezones where it tends to be inconvenient to schedule things simultaneously with Pacific time? Will they have to take the finals at the same time regardless of when that is in relation to them?</md>
Classes may change when their final exam is held, so you won't know until each class actually announces when the final is
Also, keep in mind that the enrollment system wouldn't know that info so it still won't allow you to enroll if there's a conflict & the class isn't set up to accept that.
Does this mean that, insofar as our final exam schedule has no time conflicts as displayed on CalCentral, our schedules are fine?

history.content:
As you may have noticed in the class notes for various EE & CS classes, time conflicts are NOT being allowed for many classes - even classes that have allowed them in the past.

At first glance, this seems counterintuitive because most SP21 classes are being taught remotely and many classes will be recorded or offered asynchronously.

The change in time conflict policy by some professors is the result of a change in policy at the campus level for SP21 (only). The temporary policy revision says if a professor allows time conflicts with their class, the professor is also responsible to accommodate final exam conflicts.

Many faculty do not have the resources to be able to offer alternate finals, so they are invoking their right to not allow time conflicts. (Faculty are not obligated to allow time conflicts.)

While you could ask faculty for an exception to the policy for their class if the second class is asynchronous or has no final, I'm hearing from many frustrated professors that are being overwhelmed with requests for exceptions. Perhaps a better path is to understand how the enrollment system works.

If a class does NOT allow time conflicts, enroll in that class first - at that point there will be no conflict. Then, enroll into the class that DOES allow time conflicts second. If the second class truly is set to allow time conflicts, the enrollment should go through.

WARNINGS:

  • If you choose to take this action and find out later there is a final exam conflict, it will be your responsibility to work with the faculty teaching the time-conflict-allowed class for an alternate exam. By indicating no time conflicts allowed, faculty are clearly stating they will NOT make accommodations for exam conflicts.

  • Often the enrollment system will place you on the waitlist if you do have a time conflict and attempt to enroll into a 'no time conflicts allowed' class. Be sure the pay attention to the error messages that display during the enrollment process. If you find you are 'stuck' on the waitlist, you should check to make sure you do not have a time conflict that is preventing you from enrolling.
history.subject: SP21: What's new & different with Time Conflicts
